title: Sampling Distributions and Nurse's Salaries
question_text:
A typical nurse's salary (in dollars) can range from $\$25{,}000$ to $\$55{,}000$ per year. A computer is programmed to randomly choose $20\text{ nurse's salaries}$ from among the $200\text{ nurses}$ employed at a hospital and compute the standard deviation.
The computer repeats this process a total of $50\text{ times}$. The sampling distribution of the standard deviation of the nurse's salaries is shown below.

One of the points on this sampling distribution, $\$8{,}165$, is highlighted.
What does this value represent?

choices.text:
Six nurses have a salary lower than
$
8,165
.

$
8,165
is an unusually low value for a nurse's salary at this hospital.

There is a
14
%
chance that the population standard deviation is
$
8,165
.

The standard deviation for one randomly selected sample of nurse's salaries was
$
8,165
.

The average standard deviation for the samples of nurse's salaries is
$
8,165
.

solution:
Based on the graph, we can see that this is a histogram measuring the standard deviations of the nurses' salaries. Therefore, the highlighted data point is one measure of a standard deviation of one nurse's salary.

Explanation of Distractors

Choices 'A' and 'B' - The sampling distribution displays the standard deviations from repeated samples. It does not display actual salary values for individual nurses.

Choice 'C' - Because the computer has the values of all
200
 nurse's salaries
, the population standard deviation already exists and can be found by the computer. There is no uncertainty (
14
%
chance) about the true standard deviation.

Choice 'E' - The average standard deviation of the samples of nurse's salaries can be found in the center of the sampling distribution, around
$
10,200
.
